Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: You notice a small, contained liquid spill in a walkway that needs to be O39eaned up immediately to prevent slips.
Story: I stood in the middle of the living room, my mother’s voice echoing in my ears as she handed me the ceremonial tray. “You must lead the blessing this year,” she said, her eyes shining with pride and expectation. It was our family’s tradition, and I knew how much it meant to her, to all of them. But my phone buzzed in my pocket—a message from the site supervisor. There was a spill on the walkway, and I was the only one nearby. If I didn’t clean it up right away, someone could get hurt. My hands trembled as I looked at the tray, then at the door. My family needed me to honor our traditions, to be the daughter they expected. But my crew depended on me to keep them safe, to do my job as a responsible laborer. The weight of both worlds pressed down on me, and I felt torn, caught between the pull of home and the demands of work, unsure which path to take.
